item.title: CuomoÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶ÂÅáÈáäÂßîÂëò‰ºöÂ∞ÜË≠¶ÂØüÊùÄÊâãÁöÑÂê¨ËØÅ‰ºöÊé®ËøüÂà∞DemÂ∏ÇÈïøÂàùÈÄâ‰πãÂêé | Cuomo‚Äôs NY Parole Board delays cop killer‚Äôs hearing until after Dem mayoral primary
item.description:
The state‚Äôs far-left Parole Board has quietly delayed a decision on releasing one of New York City‚Äôs most notorious cop killers¬†until after the June 24 primary ‚Äî prompting critics to speculate the move was done to help former Gov. Andrew Cuomo‚Äôs NYC mayoral bid.

The 16-member board ‚Äî 11 of whom were appointed or re-appointed by Cuomo ‚Äî was scheduled last month to review whether David McClary, a gangbanger who ruthlessly assassinated Police Officer Edward Byrne in 1988, should be released.

Byrne was a 22-year-old rookie, sitting in his patrol car in Queens, when he was shot five times in the head.

Now, the board won‚Äôt hear McClary‚Äôs bid for freedom until July, sources told The Post.

If the board ultimately releases McClary, 59, he‚Äôll be the 44th New York cop killer set free the past eight years, The Post exclusively reported last month.

Republican mayoral candidate and Guardian Angels founder Curtis¬†Sliwa¬†said he has ‚Äúno doubt‚Äù Cuomo pulled strings to delay the hearing to avoid the negative publicity of McClary‚Äôs potential release heading into a Democratic mayoral primary the ex-governor is favored to win.

‚ÄúThis makes sense since he still controls a majority of the [parole] board,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt behooves him to push this off as far as he can because it‚Äôs his¬†Achilles heel.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe does not want this to be brought up. Every time it is, it‚Äôs like a dagger to his political heart because he‚Äôs now trying to run as a law-and-order candidate.‚Äù

Most New Yorkers are unaware how many cop killers Cuomo‚Äôs handpicked board members have released, Sliwa said, adding ‚Äúmany are stunned‚Äù to hear the number when he tells them while campaigning for his own mayoral run.¬†

Councilman Robert Holden, a Queens Democrat who typically sides with Republicans, said ‚Äúthe fact that Cuomo‚Äôs parole board is delaying a vote on a cop killer until after the June primaries reeks of political gamesmanship.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a disgraceful insult to the memory of our fallen heroes and a reminder that Andrew Cuomo always puts his ambitions ahead of public safety,‚Äù he said.

The New York Parole Board did not return messages.

Referring to Sliwa, Cuomo spokesman Jason Elan said ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt comment on conspiracy theories, even ones peddled by a bereted clown.‚Äù
item.author: Tina Moore, Rich Calder

item.title: ÂïÆÈΩøÂä®Áâ©Êµ™Êº´Ôºö‰∏§Âè™Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ËÄÅÈº†Âú®È§êÂéÖÊ©±Á™óÈáå‚ÄúÊé•Âêª‚Äù | Rodent romance: Two NYC rats caught ‚Äòkissing‚Äô in restaurant window
item.description:
A pair of NYC rats were caught on video locking lips inside a Kips Bay restaurant window in what looked like an oddly tender moment ‚Äî that experts said was anything but.

Kips Bay resident Jack Knobloch stumbled upon the revolting but fascinating scene in the now-shuttered Meze Mazi restaurant on Third Avenue on May 9.

‚ÄúI was just like, this is, you know, a scene out of New York. This is crazy,‚Äù Knobloch, 34, told The Post. ‚ÄúI see rats everywhere in the city, but I‚Äôve never seen them doing anything like that.‚Äù

He said the randy rats looked like they‚Äôd been hot and heavy for a good minute.

‚ÄúIt just looked like they were kind of poking their faces together,‚Äù he said.

Knobloch, who shared the now viral video on TikTok with the caption ‚ÄúSummer love in the Big Apple‚Äù to the tune of Ratatouille‚Äôs ‚ÄúLe Festin,‚Äù woke up the next day to a flurry of comments.

The video was also reshared by New Yorkers Instagram account.

‚ÄúAnd people complain dating in New York is hard,‚Äù quipped Jonah Larrama.

But New Yorkers finding creature comfort in what appeared like a heartwarming moment will be sorely disappointed.

The vibe between the two is likely hate, not love, experts said.

‚ÄúThe rat on the left is showing a classic submissive upright posture as the rat on the right approaches ‚Äì head up, belly exposed,‚Äù said Jane Hurst, Head of Mammalian Behaviour and Evolution at the University of Liverpool.

‚ÄúYou will see that the rat on the left has nowhere to go . . . The rat on the right is then sniffing the facial area of the submissive rat, deciding whether to attack or not,‚Äù she explained.

‚ÄúIf it does, the rat on the left will have no choice but to fight back as it can‚Äôt escape.‚Äù

A 2022 inspection by the city Health Department of Meze Mazi found ‚Äúevidence of mice or live mice‚Äù and conditions that were ‚Äúconducive to attracting vermin to the premises.‚Äù

It received a ‚ÄúB‚Äù grade.

The restaurant‚Äôs website says it‚Äôs currently closed for renovations.
item.author: Gabrielle Fahmy

item.title: ‰Ωú‰∏∫ËÆÆÈïøÔºåÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇËÆÆ‰ºöÁöÑÁîü‰∫ßÂäõ‰∏ãÈôç‰∫Ü86% ÔºåÂêåÂøó‰ª¨Áé©ÂºÑÊîøÊ≤ªÔºåËÄå‰∏çÊòØÊâßÊîø | NYC Council‚Äôs productivity plummets 86% as speaker, comrades play politics instead of governing
item.description:
The City Council has seen a shocking drop-off in productivity, with its 51 members this year introducing 86% fewer bills than in 2024, The Post has learned.

Council members have introduced only 114 prospective ‚Äúlocal laws‚Äù since Jan. 21 ‚Äî the day it created a Charter Revision Commission to review ways to diminish the mayor‚Äôs authority.

Last year, the body produced 858 bills during the same period.

Council Speaker Adrienne Adams ‚Äì who is not related to her adversary, Mayor Adams ‚Äî has stretched the Council‚Äôs key central staffers thin by having some work for the commission, taking time away from their duties helping to draft bills.

Compounding this is the Democratic speaker‚Äôs longshot mayoral run announced in March ‚Äì since she‚Äôs relying on longtime staffers to run her campaign, also taking them away from their legislative duties, pols and operatives told The Post.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre definitely understaffed, and the leadership is really distracted,‚Äù said a Democratic councilmember.

‚ÄúWhen you‚Äôre pulling staff to help with the Charter Commission and other projects like that, you‚Äôre stretching Council resources, and it seems like it‚Äôs taking a long time to get bills done and back in our hands. In fact, our stated meetings lately feel pointless.‚Äù

Council resolutions ‚Äì such as non-binding ‚Äúhome rule messages‚Äù ‚Äì are also plummeting, with 155 introduced since Jan. 21, down 61% from 394 during the same period in 2024.

The creation of a bill or resolution typically begins with a coucilmember presenting the idea to central staffers ‚Äî lawyers and policy analysts in the Council‚Äôs legislative division ‚Äî who produce a draft.

The process usually took 60 days ‚Äî but this year the legislative division has requested more time on many requests, council members and aides said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs ironic when I‚Äôm trying to get a simple bill drafted but the speaker is infringing on her own democratic institution by taking away valuable resources,‚Äù said a Democratic council aide.

Four council members ‚Äì Kristy Marmorato (R-Bronx), Darlene Mealy (D-Brooklyn) Francisco Moya (D-Queens) and Inna Vernikov (R-Brooklyn) ‚Äì have yet to introduce a single piece of legislation this year.

Moya said he‚Äôs still waiting on drafts of four bills he requested earlier this year, but declined to theorize what caused the delays.

He said he‚Äôs ‚Äúaggressively pushing‚Äù for legislation he introduced last year to finally get a public hearing ‚Äî a necessity before reaching the full Council for a vote ‚Äî including some tackling quality-of-life issues like prohibiting food vendors from operating under bridges and elevated train routes.

Marmorato said she believes her time is better suited being hands-on in her district rather than drafting legislation, including working with law enforcement and educating constituents on city services.

Vernikov said her constituents aren‚Äôt looking for her ‚Äúto pass more bills that appease an unhinged, majority Democrat City Council.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat they do want is for me to continue pushing back against the bills that the radical left tries to shove down our throats, to keep fighting their Marxist agenda, and to stand up against the red tape and constant government overreach,‚Äù she added.

Mealy didn‚Äôt return messages.

‚ÄúNow that she‚Äôs running for mayor, you‚Äôd think [Adrienne Adams] would use a speaker‚Äôs main super power and do big-policy platforms through the legislative division like [former Speaker Corey Johnson] did, but there‚Äôs been no flurry of activity,‚Äù said a Democratic councilmember.

The Council‚Äôs legislative activity also plummeted during the pandemic, yet the 114 bills introduced since Jan. 21 this year barely exceeds the 96 and 113 introduced during those periods in 2020 and 2021.

During the same periods in 2022 and 2023, under Adams a speaker, there were 369 and 152 bills introduced, respectively.¬†

Council spokesperson Julia Agos insisted the speaker ‚Äúhas significantly staffed up its divisions that had previously languished, including by tripling the number of bill drafters.‚Äù

Kayla Mamelak, a spokeswoman for Mayor Adams, said the mayor ‚Äúlooks to work with the City Council every day to better the lives of New Yorkers because that‚Äôs what they elected all of them to do. It‚Äôs a shame Adrienne Adams doesn‚Äôt feel the same.‚Äù

Councilman Robert Holden, a moderate Queens Dem who usually sides with Republicans, found a silver lining in the plummeting productivity.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs clear to everyone that the speaker and her staff are focused solely on politics ‚Äî governing isn‚Äôt even an afterthought,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúFrankly, that might be a blessing in disguise, because the less this City Council does, the better off New Yorkers are.‚Äù
item.author: Rich Calder

item.title: Âç≥‰ΩøÂú®‰ª§‰∫∫Èöæ‰ª•ÁΩÆ‰ø°ÁöÑ134Ê¨°ÈÄÆÊçï‰πãÂêéÔºåÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÁöÑÂ§¥Âè∑ÊÉØÁäØ‰πüÊó†Ê≥ïÂÅúÊ≠¢ÂÅ∑Á™É | NYC‚Äôs No. 1 recidivist just can‚Äôt stop stealing ‚Äî even after mind-boggling 134 arrests
item.description:
A career crook Mayor Adams once dubbed ‚ÄúRecidivist No. 1‚Äù and the symbol of NYC‚Äôs revolving-door justice system is still circling back on crime ‚Äî his staggering rap sheet is now 134 arrests long, The Post has learned.

Harold Gooding landed on the front page of The Post in August 2022 as the person atop the NYPD‚Äôs ‚ÄúWorst of the Worst‚Äù list of repeat offenders ‚Äî and he only had 101 arrests at the time.

He‚Äôs been busted another 33 times in the 33 months since that report, records show.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs frustrating . . . for this guy to get out the same day or the next day committing the same crime he‚Äôs been doing over and over,‚Äù said a Manhattan cop who‚Äôs dealt with the 56-year-old serial thief from Brooklyn and the Bronx.

Most of the new arrests were for shoplifting from stores in Tribeca, but he‚Äôs also been collared for grand larceny and drug possession. His older arrests included armed robbery, grand larceny and burglary, the sources said.

He was slowed down a bit in June 2024 after he was arrested on grand larceny charges for shoplifting 11 different times, mostly at a Target store at 255 Greenwich St. in Tribeca, police sources said.

He pled guilty to petit larceny and was sentenced to 364 days in Rikers, police sources said. He was released in February.

And like clockwork, he‚Äôs been arrested four more times since.

The month after he got out of Rikers, he went to the Duane Reade on Broadway in Tribeca on March 28 around 10:30 a.m. and pilfered 30 bottles of vitamins worth $1,511.18, according to a criminal complaint filed with the Manhattan DA‚Äôs Office.¬†

A month later, on April 24, he went into the same store and stole cleaning supplies and three pairs of reading glasses, the records show. He was charged with grand larceny, criminal possession of stolen property, two counts of petit larceny, according to the complaint.

But in two days he was out again. The charges weren‚Äôt bail eligible. The state‚Äôs 2019 no-bail laws essentially made many lower level crimes like shoplifting penalty-free.

Four days later, on April 30, he was busted in Central Park with a crack pipe, three vials of crack, and five heroin strips in his backpack, police sources said.

The police source who knows Gooding said he‚Äôs got addiction problems ‚Äî but that it shouldn‚Äôt give him a get-out-of-jail-free card.

‚ÄúHe has a drug problem that he has to feed,‚Äù the police source said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs sad that he has to live that way but it doesn‚Äôt give him the right to commit crimes. We do our jobs arresting him and taking him in and the courts let him go.‚Äù

In the latest arrest he was given only a desk appearance ticket, and he is supposed to return to court on Monday.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not going to show up,‚Äù another police source said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs going to get a [arrest] warrant and the whole process is going to repeat itself.‚Äù

Gooding has served three prison stints, starting with a one- to three-year sentence for an attempted-burglary conviction in Brooklyn in 1994, according to state records.

Using the name Jamiel White, he was sent upstate again in 1996 for an attempted-robbery conviction in Brooklyn, according to the state Department of Corrections and Community Supervision.

His most serious conviction, for first-degree robbery in Brooklyn, landed him a 10-year sentence in 2001. He was paroled in 2008, records show.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs probably worth the squeeze for him,‚Äù said retired NYPD detective and John Jay College adjunct professor¬†Michael Alcazar. ‚ÄúIn an underground economy . . . for them, it‚Äôs worth the gamble. The police can only do so much. That‚Äôs their livelihood.‚Äù¬†

Just before he landed on the cover of the Post he was nabbed in a string of 2022 robberies, shoplifting from a Tribeca Target nearly half a dozen times, always wearing the the same distinctive white bucket hat, officials said. He was released without bail each time.

At one point, Gooding posted a glam photo on Facebook of himself wearing a baseball cap and added a sparkle effect.¬†

‚ÄúApparently he hasn‚Äôt learned his lesson nor will he,‚Äù said Joseph Giacolone, ¬†retired NYPD sergeant and adjunct professor at Penn State University-Lehigh Valley.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre living in a time we‚Äôre nobody on the City Council‚Äôs going to say this guy needs to go to jail . . . the City Council is trying to get rid of Rikers, and quite frankly, trying to abolish police. Trying to talk sense to them is futile.‚Äù

Gooding‚Äôs mother, Delores Stroy, 72, appeared surprised to learn her son was at the top of the NYPD‚Äôs ‚ÄúWorst of the Worst‚Äù list back in 2022.

‚ÄúNot my Harold,‚Äù she said.
item.author: Tina Moore, Chris Harris

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â§ßÂ≠¶ÂèØËÉΩÊó†ËßÜËá™Â∑±ÁöÑÂçèËÆÆÔºåÂÖÅËÆ∏ÂèëË°®Âèç‰ª•Ëâ≤ÂàóÁöÑÁ†îÁ©∂ÁîüË®ÄËÆ∫Ôºö INSIDER | NYU may have ignored its own protocols to allow anti-Israel grad speech: insider
item.description:
New York University may have ignored its own protocols for commencement speakers, allowing a student speaker to complete a divisive anti-Israel speech at its Gallatin School graduation ‚Äî as some faculty members applauded, a school insider told The Post.

‚ÄúAs I search my my heart . . . the only thing that is appropriate to say in this time and to a group this large is a recognition of the atrocities currently happening in Palestine,‚Äù student Logan Rozos said Wednesday in the opening of his three-minute speech laced with a one-sided narrative about the Israel-Gaza war.

‚ÄúI want to say that I condemn this genocide and condemn the complicity in this genocide,‚Äù he said claiming the US was ‚Äúmilitarily and politically‚Äù complicit, as faculty on the dais were seen applauding and nodding emphatically.

An NYU insider who‚Äôs been at the school decades told The Post Rozos should have never been allowed to finish his speech.

Students have to ‚Äúsubmit a copy of the speech and agree to read that speech and none other,‚Äù the insider said.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs definitely a breakdown in protocol. When someone goes off script, the mic is supposed to be cut. These events are produced to the syllable because they need to be.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs supposed to be zero surprises ‚Äì 100 percent by design.‚Äù

The insider added that ‚Äúthe real question is if there were faculty on the inside who put him up to this.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy mind, seeing all the faculty on the stage clapping, caused me to question whether they were in some way involved or not,‚Äù said the source, noting their robust record of anti-Israel sentiment according to the Canary Mission, which tracks antisemitism.

Fellow grads were aghast NYU allowed Rozos to finish the ‚Äúinflammatory‚Äù and ‚Äúincredibly narcissistic‚Äù diatribe at the Beacon Theatre ceremony.

‚ÄúThey absolutely should have cut it off and not applauded him,‚Äù fumed Sabrina Maslavi, a Gallatin grad who settled a federal antimsemitism lawsuit with NYU last year.

Maslavi told the Post that the ‚Äúinappropriate‚Äù speech ‚Äúdefinitely ruined my graduation for me and my family,‚Äù estimating about half of faculty on the dais openly supported the screed. ‚ÄúThey applauded him and let him finish. And after he sat down, the faculty still applauded him.‚Äù

She claimed she was shunned when she didn‚Äôt follow fellow grads in giving him a standing ovation.

‚ÄúI got the death stare.‚Äù

Another grad groused about the ‚Äúhorrible‚Äù and ‚Äúembarrassing‚Äù spectacle for the institution.

‚ÄúIt took any prestige they had and squashed it,‚Äù the grad said, adding that Rozos ‚Äúshould have been pulled off the stage.‚Äù

Gallatin dean Victoria Rosner took the stage directly after Rozos, ignoring the divisive rant.

Hours after the speech, an NYU spokesperson announced it would be withholding Rozos‚Äôs diploma while it ‚Äúpursues disciplinary actions.‚Äù

The school said Rozos ‚Äúabused‚Äù his ‚Äúprivilege,‚Äù ‚Äúdenounc[ing]‚Äù Rozos‚Äôs speech and accusing him of ‚Äúmisus[ing] his role as student speaker to express his personal and one-sided political views.‚Äù

The rep did not address any breach in protocol but said the student ‚Äúlied about the speech he was going to deliver and violated the commitment he made to comply with our rules.‚Äù

The 24-year-old Rozos, who wrote in a student online platform that he was raised in Washington Heights and the Bronx, was honored in 2020 for his ‚Äúgroundbreaking‚Äù role in the series ‚ÄúDavid Makes Men‚Äù on the Oprah Winfrey Network. ‚ÄúAt the time, Rozos was one of very few trans men on television,‚Äù read the 2024 Glaad writeup.

The Post reached out to Rozos multiple times for comment.

Students think that the punishment will only boost Rozos‚Äôs notoriety, transforming him into a hero.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing that NYU could do to make him regret what he said,‚Äù said a Jewish male grad who was appalled at the ceremony. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if Logan turns into a victim from this‚Äî a victim of Israel and the Jewish people. People are going to feel bad for him.‚Äù

Jeff Rabhan, father of a Gallatin grad, ripped NYU, where he previously worked for 11 years.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt tell me they didn‚Äôt discuss the possibility of this happening,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThere was plenty of opportunity to right the wrong,‚Äù seethed the dad about not cutting off the student, noting ‚Äúit‚Äôs offensive for families who spend $250,000‚Äù for the NYU degree.

Watchdog groups condemned the message sent by NYU‚Äôs slap in the wrist.

‚ÄúWe fail to see how New York University has made any positive changes to deter ‚Äì or impose consequences on ‚Äì Jew-hatred when this is the speech given at commencement to rounding applause but no condemnation,‚Äù said Michelle Ahdoot of End Jewish Hatred, which first published the graduation video.
item.author: Doree Lewak

item.title: Ëé∑ÂæóËâæÁæéÂ•ñÁöÑÊó•ËÆ∞Â£∞Áß∞Â•πÁöÑÁÉ≠Â∏¶Â§©Â†ÇË¢´Èò¥ÊöóÁöÑÊãçÂçñÂ∏à‰ªéÂ•π‰∏ãÈù¢ÂçñÊéâ‰∫Ü | Emmy-winning journo claims her tropical paradise was sold out from under her by shady auctioneer
item.description:
An Emmy-award winning journalist claims in a lawsuit her $6 million tropical mansion was sold out from under her by a sleazy auctioneer.

Cathleen Trigg-Jones, who launched iWomanTV and won an Emmy in 2003 for education reporting while at WWOR in New York City, slammed Concierge Auctions in Florida for what she called ‚Äúblatant misogyny,‚Äù according to a $10 million lawsuit filed in Manhattan Federal Court.

Trigg-Jones, 57, and her doctor husband Michael Jones bought the four-bedroom, four-bath beachfront townhouse in exclusive Bahia Beach Resort & Golf Club just outside San Juan in 2014.

The 4-204-square-foot property features cathedral ceilings, French doors, multiple walk-in closets and a private plunge pool, according to a real estate listing which pegs the value of the property at $5.9 million.

Michael Jones contacted Concierge about selling the property but Trigg-Jones alleged she had immediate doubts.

‚ÄúConcierge seemed to Mrs. Jones to be running a scam,‚Äù she said in the Manhattan Federal Court lawsuit, adding the Florida-based outfit appears to sell ‚Äúto Concierge‚Äôs own cabal of bidders, through non-market auctions, for amounts significantly less than a fair market value.‚Äù

‚ÄúApparently, this auctioneer doesn‚Äôt think a woman should have the right to review a contract separate and apart from her husband,‚Äù Trigg-Jones said in the legal filing.

Even though Michael Jones notified the auction company that his wife was reviewing the agreement with an attorney and had not signed, Concierge allegedly held an auction in March anyway, ‚Äúselling‚Äù the home for $4.2 million, according to the complaint and Trigg-Jones‚Äô attorney.

Then it allegedly ruined her rep by having its agents tell neighbors and real estate professionals she reneged on the deal, she claimed in the suit.

Trigg-Jones ‚Äúnever entered into an agreement with Concierge for the sale of her property,‚Äù she said in the lawsuit.

The ‚Äúpurported buyer,‚Äù hedge funder Michael Nachmani, ‚Äúhas threatened to sue Mrs. Jones and is demanding that she close on the purported auction sale,‚Äù she said in the lawsuit.

She wants a judge ‚Äúto step in to clarify her rights and to award her damage resulting from the harm to her reputation which the auction company has already caused and continues to cause.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have dedicated my life and career to fighting for women‚Äôs rights and equality. When Concierge Auctions tried to bypass me, and sell my home without my signature, my consent, or legal review, I was shocked,‚Äù Trigg-Jones said in a statement.

‚ÄúEven as an equal owner, I was treated as if my voice and my rights don‚Äôt matter. This is not just illegal, it‚Äôs unethical ‚Äî misogyny, plain and simple, and it is an insult to every woman who‚Äôs ever had to fight for respect.‚Äù

Nachmani declined comment.

In response to a request for comment, Concierge claimed Michael Jones had signed an auction agreement and given his permission to launch the auction.

Trigg-Jones‚Äô accusations are an ‚Äúintentionally incomplete false and misleading narrative,‚Äù Concierge alleged.
item.author: Kathianne Boniello

item.title: ÊéíË°åÊ¶úÊ¶úÈ¶ñÁöÑÊ≠åÊâãÂú®ÂçïÊõ≤ÂêéÊ∂àÂ§±‰∫Ü‚ÄîÁé∞Âú®Â•πÊòØÂùöÈüß‰∏çÊãîÁöÑÂè≤Âù¶È°øÂ≤õÁöÑË≠¶ÂØü | Chart-topping singer vanished after hit single ‚Äî¬†now she‚Äôs a cop in gritty Staten Island
item.description:
A one-hit wonder who disappeared from the public eye after rocketing to stardom with a No. 1 song in the UK and sexy bathtub snaps in Maxim magazine has been quietly working as a Staten Island cop for the last decade, The Post has learned.

Nicole F. Aiello¬†performed under the stage name Frankee and had a chart-topping hit with ‚ÄúF‚Äìk You Right Back‚Äù in 2004. But after the single from her next album fizzled in 2006, she was dumped by her label and vanished ‚Äî spending the next 10 years off the grid.

In 2016, she decided that instead of busting a move on stage she would bust perps in the 121st Precinct on the gritty north shore of Staten Island.

Frankee‚Äôs hit topped the UK charts and rose to No. 63 in the US Billboard Hot 100 in 2004.

Her song was a response to a hit tune by R&B singer Eamon Doyle called ‚ÄúF‚Äìk it (I don‚Äôt want you back).‚Äù¬†

In his tune, laden with cheesy lyrics, Eamon lashes out at an ex-girlfriend for cheating: ‚ÄúI do admit I‚Äôm sad, it hurts real bad, I can‚Äôt sweat that ‚Äôcause I loved a hoe.‚Äù

Frankee‚Äôs answer put the blame back on him, even though the two never met.

‚ÄúF‚Äìk what I did, was your fault some how,‚Äù she sings, after she throws what appear to be gifts at him in the accompanying music video. ‚ÄúF‚Äìk the presents, I threw all that s‚Äìt out. F‚Äìk off that cryin‚Äô, it didn‚Äôt mean jack. Well guess what yo. F‚Äìk you right back.‚Äù

The video opens with several young scantily-clad women giggling on a bed before Frankee opens a window to see the supposed boyfriend in the driveway and begins with the lyric, ‚ÄúThere are two sides to every story.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou thought you could really make me moan,‚Äù she croons. ‚ÄúI had better sex all alone. . . . Now you want me to come back. You must be smokin‚Äô crack. . . . F‚Äìk all those nights you thought you broke my back. Well guess what yo, your sex was wack.‚Äù

Maxim Magazine did a naughty photo-filled profile on Frankee in 2006, who was asked about the song.

‚ÄúEveryone took the song seriously, but I was just being funny,‚Äù she was quoted as saying. ‚ÄúEveryone goes through that angry ‚ÄòI hate men‚Äô phase because some guy broke their heart but now I‚Äôm looking at the good side of life ‚Äì having fun, being sexy.‚Äù¬†¬†

Ironically, the magazine asked her if she had any run-ins with the law and she responded that she had been in trouble as a teenager for fighting at clubs in Staten Island, where she grew up.

‚ÄúHow many times have you been hauled down to the station?‚Äù the mag asked.

‚ÄúAt least three in the past couple of years,‚Äù she replied. ‚ÄúO.K., five. I‚Äôve probably been in 20 fights.‚Äù

Frankee released another single titled ‚ÄúWatch me‚Äù in 2006 but it failed to chart and then she disappeared from public view.

She has worked in the 121st Precinct since February 2017 and made $181,000 last year, city records show.

Last year, Metro.co.uk published a story with the headline: ‚ÄúWhatever happened to FURB singer Frankee? Apparently, nobody knows.‚Äù

Now 42, her¬†under-the-radar identity came to light after the tragic death of her husband, John Spinelli, 46, on May 12, police sources said.

His death is mourned on a GoFundMe page seeking donations for the widow and the couple‚Äôs two young daughters, 4 and 10.

‚ÄúThis unimaginable heartbreak has turned their world upside down,‚Äù the posting, which had raised more than $100,000 as of Friday, states. ‚ÄúJohn was a devoted father, a steady presence, and a source of love and security for his family. His passing has left an emotional void that no family should have to face alone.‚Äù
item.author: Tina Moore

item.title: ËÅîÈÇ¶Êä•ÂëäÊè≠Á§∫‰∫ÜÁ•ûÁßòÊó†‰∫∫Êú∫ÁõÆÂáª‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁöÑÂéüÂõ†‚Äî‰ΩÜ‰∏ªË¶ÅÁöÑË∞úÂõ¢‰ªçÁÑ∂Â≠òÂú® | Federal report reveals the cause of mysterious drone sightings ‚Äî but major mystery remains
item.description:
Federal officials knew in mid-December that some of the mysterious drones spotted in the skies over New Jersey and New York were authorized aircraft ‚Äî but withheld that information from the American public, as President Trump suggested many months ago.

An internal slideshow presentation arranged by Transportation Security Administration officials debunked four of the New Jersey drone sightings as optical illusions created by sanctioned aircraft.

‚ÄúThe alignment of the aircraft gave the appearance to observers on the ground of them hovering in formation while they were actually moving directly at the observers,‚Äù reads a slide about several reported sightings over Somerville, NJ the night of Nov. 26, 2024.

The slides were first shared by Reason.com, and also included an explanation for the three drone sightings over the Salem Nuclear Power Plant and the adjacent Hope Creek Generating Station on Dec. 12, 2024 ‚Äî a day before the Federal Aviation Administration imposed airspace restrictions over New Jersey.

The report dispels Dec. 5, 2024, sightings of drones along the Jersey coastline as ‚Äúaircraft arriving
from the South on approach into JFK‚Äù that ‚Äúturned toward land around Sea Girt, flying for 2 to 3 minutes toward the coast, turning back out to sea, and flying 3 to 5 minutes straight away from the coast.‚Äù

Those aircraft ‚Äî a Cessna C150 and UH-60 Black Hawk ‚Äì would‚Äôve appeared to hover in the sky to anyone on the ground, according to the feds. Both aircraft were authorized to be in the area.

A second Dec. 12 account of a drone over Clifton, N.J., dispersing some sort of a gray mist was also dismissed as another plane: a Beechcraft Baron 58, which experienced turbulence, ‚Äúdropped approximately 100 feet before regaining altitude.‚Äù

The rapid change ‚Äúover the wing‚Äôs surfaces cause wingtip vertices,‚Äù or condensation clouds, ‚Äúthat may appear as gray mist.‚Äù

But the incomplete presentation failed to address some of the more notable sightings, including the swarm of 12 to 30 drones spotted Dec. 8 over the Atlantic by patrolling members of the U.S. Coast Guard.

A sailor who spoke to The Post about the incident said they were sent out to look for drones when ‚Äúthey found us.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey appeared out of nowhere‚Äù at about 9 p.m., and followed the boat for approximately 15 minutes, he said. When the vessel shifted course, so too did the drones.

‚ÄúThey had four propellers. Seven feet across. The flashing lights, like you‚Äôve seen. The festive green, red, and white lights.‚Äù

Trump accused the Biden administration in January of knowingly keeping New York and New Jersey residents ‚Äúin suspense.‚Äù

Added Trump: ‚ÄúFor some reason, they don‚Äôt want to tell the people, and they should. Our military knows and our president knows. And for some reason, they want to keep people in suspense.‚Äù

In December, Biden said there was ‚Äúnothing nefarious‚Äù in the sky. Members of Congress concurred following a classified briefing.
item.author: Chris Harris

item.title: Áî±ÂàáÂ∞îË•ø¬∑ÂÖãÊûóÈ°øÔºà Chelsea Clinton ÔºâÊîØÊåÅÁöÑËø∑‰∫∫Â≠ï‰∫ßÂàùÂàõ‰ºÅ‰∏öÂõ†ÁñèÂøΩËÄåË¢´Ëµ∑ËØâÔºöÊ≥ïÂ∫≠Êñá‰ª∂ | Glamorous maternity start-up backed by Chelsea Clinton sued for negligence: Court docs
item.description:
A multi-million dollar maternity start-up backed by Chelsea Clinton which promised to revolutionize the way women give birth, has been hit with a lawsuit ‚Äî the second in as many years alleging medical malpractice, The Post has learned.

Oula ‚Äî which provides midwife care from four boutique clinics in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Norwalk, Conn. ‚Äî is being sued by Vantisha Knowles for ‚Äúnegligently acting outside the applicable standard of care,‚Äù according to court papers filed in New York State Supreme Court in March.

Knowles, 39, who is a realtor, said she went to Oula when having her second child, a daughter.

She had been looking for a clinic that worked with midwives and ‚Äúthey were great for pre-natal‚Äù but when she went to give birth it turned into ‚Äúa traumatic experience‚Äù.

‚ÄúThey basically rushed me through labor and did a C-section,‚Äù she told The Post, adding the experience was so bad it has contributed to her decision not to have any more children.

In her complaint is says Knowles ‚Äúsustained grave and permanent injuries‚Äù during the C-section, without going into specifics.

Speaking to The Post, Knowles says after getting home, after she called Oula to describe her injuries ‚Äúthey just told me to go to emergency. They had not solutions for me. Why couldn‚Äôt I just go through them?‚Äù

Knowles said she needed to be hospitalized and to have blood transfusions.¬†‚ÄúThey just don‚Äôt care,‚Äù she claimed.

Knowles‚Äô suit also names Mount Sinai Hospital and Ila Dayananda, an obstetrician/gynecologist and former chief medical officer for Planned Parenthood of Greater New York, who works for Oula.

‚ÄúThe defendants, their agents, and/or employees failed to provide reasonable medical care and deviated from accepted medical practice in the care, treatment, evaluation, management, and services provided to the plaintiff,‚Äù her legal papers claim.

The charges she levels at the clinic are negligently ‚Äúfailing to properly evaluate plaintiff to determine the necessity of performing a C-section delivery of her baby, by failing to properly wait for plaintiff‚Äôs labor and delivery to progress; by failing to take into account plaintiff‚Äôs prior medical history,‚Äù the lawsuit reads.

In 2023, Oula ‚Äî which is affiliated with Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City ‚Äî was hit with a lawsuit by a Brooklyn couple who claimed its negligence led to their baby being born badly brain-damaged. That lawsuit is ongoing, court records show.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre growing fast, but they don‚Äôt seem to understand their own business,‚Äù said a source, who claimed the start-up has lost a handful of midwives at the clinics in the last several months.

‚ÄúOula is a rudderless ship. A lot of the midwives are burned out, and scared they will be hit with malpractice suits.‚Äù

In a response to The Post‚Äôs request for comment, Oula said: ‚ÄúWe do not comment on medical claims due to healthcare privacy laws.‚Äù

Oula‚Äôs star-studded promotional events have featured CBS News anchor Gayle King, ballerina Misty Copeland and Seagram‚Äôs heiress Hannah Bronfman, while its woke social media includes motivational quotes for ‚Äúbirthing people.‚Äù

The clinics also feature spa-like interiors that resemble high-end boutique hotels.

Oula is one of a number of start-ups aiming to cash in on a potentially lucrative change in the Affordable Care Act, which ordered insurers to pay for midwife-led care for pregnant women.

The change was prompted by concern that mothers in the US have exceptionally high rates of birth by C-section and that maternal mortality rates are too high.

More than 32 percent of live births in the US were caesarian deliveries in 2022, according to the March of Dimes.

This is more than double what the World Health Organization deems ideal for caesarian births,¬†at 10 percent to 15 percent.

Oula, which opened its first clinic in 2021, was started by Harvard grad Adrianne Nickerson, who has degrees in biology and global health, as well as Elaine Purcell, who has a master‚Äôs in health care administration from New York University, according to their LinkedIn profiles.

Oula‚Äôs secured $28 million from a fund run by investors, including Clinton, who also has a master‚Äôs in public health from Columbia University. That funding allowed Oula to open its first clinics in Lower Manhattan, Brooklyn, and Norwalk. The firm also has offices on the Upper West Side.

‚ÄúVery proud to be an investor in Oula as they continue to build a midwife-centered care model that has better outcomes for mothers & babies alike,‚Äù¬†Clinton posted on X¬†in December 2023.
item.author: Isabel Vincent

item.title: Ê∫∫Áà±Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ÁöÑ‚ÄúÁà∏Áà∏Èó®Âç´‚ÄùÂú®Ê≠åÊõ≤‰∏≠ÁñØ‰º†ÔºåË∑≥ËàûÔºö ‚ÄúÊØèÂ§©ÈÉΩÈúÄË¶ÅËøôÁßçËÉΩÈáè‚Äù | Doting NYC ‚Äòdaddy doorman‚Äô goes viral for songs, dancing: ‚ÄòNeed this energy every day‚Äô
item.description:
They‚Äôre floored by this NYC doorman.

Wilby Martinez is the Internet‚Äôs new obsession, with videos of him singing, dancing and ‚Äúhyping up‚Äù a tenant in his Brooklyn building going viral.

‚ÄúMy angel of a doorman serenades me every morning,‚Äù Abigail Olshavsky captioned a TikTok video showing Martinez, 30, skipping around the lobby, singing.

Martinez showers tenants of the Park Slope building with compliments as they walk through the lobby.

‚ÄúWhere are you going . . . looking all nice,‚Äù Martinez says, looking Olshavsky, 27, up and down as she leaves on her way to dinner, as seen in another video she posted on TikTok last month.

Martinez‚Äôs sweet ‚ÄúGolden Retriever‚Äù energy, as Olshavsky calls it, went viral, prompting the brand manager to change her TikTok bio to, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre probably here for the doorman.‚Äù

In another clip, Martinez, a Lower East Side native who has worked in the building for two years, can be seen skipping in the lobby singing, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fun to say ‚Äògood morning,‚Äô good morning to you.‚Äù

In another, Olshavsky delivers him homemade cookies, warning that they didn‚Äôt turn out well.

Nonetheless, he gasps with excitement ‚Äî and she captioned the video saying he loved them.

In another post, a flabbergasted Martinez reacts to the news that their April 27 video got more than 2.8 million views.

‚ÄúDid you always know you were going to be a star?‚Äù Olshavsky asks. ‚ÄúCut it out,‚Äù a coy Martinez says before admitting, ‚ÄúI was prom king.‚Äù

His popularity is apparent in the comment section, where women gush over his dimples, nervous energy and slightly crooked tie.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs CUTE,‚Äù one proclaimed.

Followers even noticed when Martinez got a haircut. ‚ÄúHe cut his hair???‚Äù one wrote. ‚ÄúOwwweeee now we‚Äôre talkin.‚Äù

Some even call him ‚Äúdaddy doorman.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know he likes you, but can you ask him if he likes me?‚Äù another TikToker ventured.

Many comments informed Olshavsky that Martinez is flirting and in love with her ‚Äî a rumor she squashed in a video saying ‚Äúyou don‚Äôt s‚Äìt where you eat‚Äù ‚Äî but the unexpected pair insist their upbeat personalities made them fast friends.

Their first interaction came after Olshavsky moved into the building in February, when Martinez helped her move a couch she was struggling to drag down to the lobby.

‚ÄúHe was more than willing to help,‚Äù she told The Post. ‚ÄúJust such an amazing, nice person ‚Äî the energy that I want when I‚Äôm coming and going every day.‚Äù

She decided to film their day to day and her followers couldn‚Äôt get enough.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre like, ‚ÄòI want him as my doorman. I need this energy every day.‚Äô So if I can continue to provide that, that‚Äôs something that I want to do.‚Äù

As for Martinez, all he needs is the smiles from the building residents, all of whom he has come to know.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need any more motivation to be energetic than to see people happy when they leave their home,‚Äù he said.

The duo swears they‚Äôll remain in touch no matter where they work or live next.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs part of my life now and I love him being in it!‚Äù Olshavsky said.
item.author: Georgia Worrell, Deirdre Bardolf

item.title: „ÄäÂçéÁõõÈ°øÈÇÆÊä•„Äã‰∏éÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë≠¶ÂØüÂ±Ä‰∏ÄËµ∑ËøõË°åÊµÅÊµ™Â∑°ÈÄªÔºö ‚ÄúÊàë‰ª¨‰∏çËÉΩÂº∫Ëø´‰ªñ‰ª¨‚Äù‰∏ãÂú∞ÈìÅËøõÂÖ•ÈÅøÈöæÊâÄ | The Post tagged along on vagrant patrol with the NYPD: ‚ÄòWe can‚Äôt force them‚Äô off subways into shelters
item.description:
It was an offer they could refuse.

Cops and social workers faced the monumental task this week of convincing unhinged vagrants living in Penn and Herald Square stations to trust them ‚Äî and accept their offer of help.

Only one did ‚Äî at least during the two hours that The Post tagged along Wednesday night from 8:30 p.m. to about 10:30 p.m.

Nine members of Mayor Adams‚Äô Partnership Assistance for Transit Homelessness (PATH) team ‚Äî six cops, two social workers and a nurse ‚Äî¬†approached 12 vagrants with the chance to sleep in a warm bed. The program began in August.

‚ÄúDo you want to go to a shelter? Do you need help?‚Äù team members asked one elderly man lying atop two grungy cushions on the floor at East 32nd Street and Sixth Avenue.

He said he was already receiving medical help, quickly gathered his belongings and shuffled away.

‚ÄúI was trying to see if he would go to the hospital,‚Äù nurse Richard Perkins said, noting the man had an obvious hernia. ‚ÄúWe try to help him every night but he doesn‚Äôt want help.‚Äù

Transit Bureau Police Officer Ronny Del Rosario, 25, has gotten to know ‚ÄúStu‚Äù and also frequently tries to help him.

‚ÄúWe always worry about him,‚Äù said Rosario, who‚Äôs been on the job for two years. ‚ÄúSleeping on the floor every day isn‚Äôt safe.‚Äù

A 26-year-old transgendered man known as Justin ‚Äì who had one bare foot ‚Äì initially accepted the ride to a shelter and waited outside Penn Station in the rain with the team for 20 minutes ‚Äì but then suddenly changed his mind and scurried off through puddles along Seventh Avenue.

‚ÄúHe said he was overwhelmed,‚Äù said James Goodwin, a community coordinator at the Department of Homeless Services, looking dejected. ‚ÄúWe continue to try because these are our mothers, fathers, brothers and sisters.‚Äù

NYPD Capt. Hanjie Lu, who led the police officers, followed Justin and got him to agree to go to what he called a ‚Äúwarming bus‚Äù parked nearby at Seventh Avenue.

‚ÄúThe next shift is at 3:30 a.m.,‚Äù said Lu. ‚ÄúIf we see him then, we will try again.‚Äù¬†

Only one man, who was slumped over on a subway platform bench agreed to be taken to a Brooklyn shelter, but it was one he was already assigned to, officials said. ¬†

‚ÄúA lot of them, the first couple times we talk to them they‚Äôre going to refuse,‚Äù said Lu. ‚ÄúEventually, they‚Äôll accept the services, maybe not connecting them to a shelter but get them off the platform to get something to eat, to shower, get some clean clothing.‚Äù

The mayor‚Äôs office created PATH to combine the services of nurses, social workers and cops under one umbrella, officials said.¬†The teams conduct outreach at stations in Manhattan from 8 p.m. to 12 p.m. seven days a week. They hope to expand the program citywide.

‚ÄúWe keep trying because these are our mothers, fathers, aunts, uncles,‚Äù said Goodwin. ‚ÄúSo shouldn‚Äôt we help them?

‚ÄúOne of the most unfortunate things is that we can‚Äôt force them to take services,‚Äù he added.

Officers can force a person to go to an emergency room with a 72-hour hold under state law after a nurse evaluates them. The protocol is known as a ‚Äú9.58,‚Äù for the section of the state‚Äôs mental hygiene law that allows a nurse to remove a person who‚Äôs a danger to themself or others.

‚ÄúLast week, a person had active lice,‚Äù Goodwin noted, explaining that a 9.58 was called and the man was taken to a hospital. ‚ÄúWe could not let that person back on the train.‚Äù

He also recalled a homeless man who was forced to go to an ER because he was shooting drugs into an open wound.

Dark corridors and corners at stations allow for the illicit behavior, Goodwin said.

One hallway in Herald Square‚Äôs station was littered with discarded needles, The Post observed.

PATH¬†teams have had contact with vagrants more than¬†13,500¬†times and provided services ‚Äî everything from getting them beds, meals, clothes or even identification ‚Äî nearly 4,000 times,¬†according to city officials.

Cops also issued 390 summonses and removed over 1,000 people from the system for various violations.¬†

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs innovative programs like this that keep New Yorkers safe and ensure the lifeblood of our city, our subway system, is able to thrive,‚Äù said Mayor Adams, who successfully pushed the state to permit a wider use of involuntary commitments that passed in the state budget last week. ‚ÄØ

NYPD Sgt. Allan Rinvil, a 43-year-old with 18 years on the job, was at the station last Friday when the team found a man with dementia at Penn Station.

‚ÄúWe ended up getting him care and into shelter,‚Äù recalled Rinvil, who said he signed up for the team because he wanted to help. ‚ÄúBut that was just one good night. We have many good nights.‚Äù
item.author: Tina Moore

item.title: ÁâπÊúóÊôÆÊîØÊåÅÁöÑÊñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÂ∑ûÊîøÂ∫úÂÄôÈÄâ‰∫∫Êù∞ÂÖã¬∑Â§èÂ°îÈõ∑Âà©Ôºà Jack Ciattarelli ÔºâÂèëË™ìË¶ÅÊä•Â§çÊã•Â†µÂÆö‰ª∑Ôºö ‚ÄúÊàë‰ª¨‰∏ç‰ºöË¢´Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Êé®Êù•Êé®Âéª‚Äù | Trump-backed NJ gov hopeful Jack Ciattarelli vows congestion pricing revenge: ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre not going to be pushed around by New York‚Äô
item.description:
The congestion pricing apocalypse could be coming.

President Trump‚Äôs choice to become New Jersey‚Äôs next governor has a message for New York: drop the congestion tolling scheme ‚Äî or pay the price.

Republican Jack Ciattarelli is vowing to slap a ‚Äúreverse congestion pricing‚Äù fee on all New York vehicles entering the Garden State if he wins the race to replace term-limited Democratic Gov. Phil Murphy.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not going to be pushed around by New York,‚Äù Ciattarelli told The Post.

The 63-year-old frontrunner in the June 10 GOP primary said, if elected, he‚Äôll set up toll cameras along bridges and tunnels entering Jersey to ID New York license plates, so that vehicle owners could be billed the same $9 fees most drivers pay to enter Manhattan below 60th Street ‚Äî unless Gov. Hochul puts the brakes on congestion pricing as Trump has demanded.

Revenues collected would go towards upgrading state-owned NJ Transit ‚Äî just as New York‚Äôs scheme is used to raise funds to improve its dilapidated mass transit.

‚ÄúWe will replicate the New York model,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf this is what they are going to do to New Jerseyans, this is going to be what we will do to New Yorkers.¬†New York needs to fix its subway system on its own, just as we‚Äôre trying to fix [NJ] Transit on our own.‚Äù

Regarding the NJ Transit strike, he said it should be illegal for train engineers to walk off the job because the public depends on them to safely travel ‚Äì just as it is for federal air traffic controllers. He said he wants to ‚Äúexamine‚Äù the feasibility of such a policy.

Ciattarelli, a former state assemblyman representing part of Hunterdon County in central Jersey, said he would¬†carry out Trump‚Äôs policy agenda, including ending New Jersey‚Äôs sanctuary state status and scrapping bail reform laws that help put violent criminals back on the street.

‚ÄúI think that every governor should work in partnership with the president on securing our borders and not welcoming the illegal immigrants to our states,‚Äù he said.

During the 2021 election, Trump strategically stood on the sidelines of the New Jersey gubernatorial race because New Jersey historically leans blue. However a stronger-than-anticipated showing in the Garden State during last year‚Äôs presidential race compared to 2016 and 2020 no longer makes his endorsement there a liability, despite Democrats outnumbering Republicans by roughly 800,000 registered voters.

Ciattarelli predicted¬†Trump‚Äôs endorsement will not only help him win the primary ‚Äî but also the general election in November after losing the same race four years earlier to Murphy by a mere three percentage points.

‚ÄúThis endorsement is very important in terms of bringing awareness to New Jersey, certainly awareness of my candidacy,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe president believes I‚Äôm the only one who could win in November, and I greatly appreciate his faith, trust and confidence.‚Äù

Ciattarelli‚Äôs main competition in the primary are former conservative talk show host Bill Spadea and New Jersey Sen. Jon Bramnick (R-Union).

Ciattarelli declined to discuss his GOP opponents or most of the six candidates running in a hotly contested Democratic primary ‚Äì except Newark Mayor Ras Baraka. He called Baraka‚Äôs arrest last week for trespassing while protesting outside a Newark immigration detention facility a ‚Äúpublicity stunt.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is a mayor of a town that has crime in the streets,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not showing up in the schools or showing up at crime scenes. Newark Airport is in the midst of an unprecedented meltdown, . . . yet he‚Äôs showing up to a detention center where the federal government is detaining people who came here illegally, who then committed crimes. I don‚Äôt understand what it is we‚Äôre protesting.‚Äù

Baraka‚Äôs spokesperson Kabir Moss shot down Ciattarelli‚Äôs claim that Newark has fallen on hard times and insisted the mayor wasn‚Äôt trespassing.

‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt go there to get arrested; he went to join a press conference with congress members,‚Äù Moss said. ‚ÄúBut if Jack Ciattarelli can‚Äôt recognize the Constitutional crisis we‚Äôre in ‚Äî where due process is being denied on American soil ‚Äî then he‚Äôs not fit to be governor.‚Äù¬†

Hochul‚Äôs office did not return messages.
item.author: Rich Calder

item.title: Êó†ÊÉÖÁöÑÈïøÂ≤õÂè∏Êú∫Á†çÂÄí‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÂÆ∂‰∫∫ÁöÑÈπÖ‚ÄîÂ∞ΩÁÆ°Â•ΩÊííÁéõÂà©‰∫ö‰∫∫ÊÅ≥Ê±ÇÊîæÊÖ¢ÈÄüÂ∫¶ | Heartless Long Island driver mows down family of geese ‚Äî despite pleas from good Samaritan to slow down
item.description:
A fowl scene unfolded on a Long Island highway when a heartless driver slammed into a family of geese despite pleas from a good Samaritan to slow down ‚Äî killing the adults and two of their goslings.

The massacre on Veterans Highway in Islandia left Coleen DeLorenzo in tears.

DeLorenzo, 58, was on her way to work and heading north Thursday morning when she spotted the two adult geese and their six feathery babies crossing the four-lane thoroughfare just before the Long Island Expressway.

‚ÄúEverybody stopped,‚Äù the Patchogue resident told The Post. ‚ÄúThese geese were in a very perilous part of the road. . . . I saw them from a mile away.‚Äù

She put her hazard lights on and was getting out of the car when she looked over her shoulder and saw a blue van that wasn‚Äôt slowing down.

‚ÄúIt was a Disabled American Veterans van, and they were flying,‚Äù DeLorenzo said. ‚ÄúI waved my hands, they never even looked up. They hit the entire family of geese. They obliterated them at 50, 60 miles per hour.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis van never even tapped the brake.‚Äù

Devastated, DeLorenzo ‚Äústarted running around trying to save the goslings.

‚ÄúI picked up one baby that was hit, I thought maybe we could save it,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt died in my hands.‚Äù

A young couple eventually helped her gather four surviving goslings, while workers doing construction nearby stepped in and used their trucks to block traffic.

‚ÄúI was sobbing, covered in blood. They came over and blocked the traffic and used tarps to cover the bodies and move them, made sure I was ok.‚Äù

DeLorenzo and the couple helping her eventually made contact with Sweetbriar Nature Center in Smithtown, which took in the survivors and posted about the incident on social media.

Janine Bendicksen, director of wildlife rehabilitation at the center, said the surviving Canada geese are doing fine.

‚ÄúThe thing is, you know when you hit and kill something. You hear it, feel it. And to just keep going?‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThat is the tragedy of it all.‚Äù

The center, which posted an emotional video of DeLorenzo pleading with people to slow down, takes in nearly 3,000 animals a year, ‚Äúeverything from eagles, hawks, owls, foxes, you name it,‚Äù she said.

The incident has left DeLorenzo shaken.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sick over it. It was such a violent act it will never go out of my head,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúThat any human being could lay their head down and sleep at night after doing what they did ‚Äî I feel lost.‚Äù

Disabled American Veterans, the organization whose name was on the van, could not immediately be reached for comment.
item.author: Kathianne Boniello

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â§ßÂ≠¶Êâ£Áïô‰∫ÜÂú®ÊØï‰∏öÂÖ∏Á§ºÊºîËÆ≤‰∏≠Ë∞¥Ë¥£Âä†Ê≤ô‚ÄúÁßçÊóèÁÅ≠Áªù‚ÄùÁöÑÂ≠¶ÁîüÁöÑÊñáÂá≠‚ÄîÊ≠£Â¶ÇDemÊâÄËØ¥Ôºå ‚ÄúÁ•ù‰Ω†Â•ΩËøêÊâæÂ∑•‰Ωú‚Äù | NYU withholds diploma from student who decried ‚Äògenocide‚Äô in Gaza during commencement speech ‚Äî as Dem says, ‚ÄòGood luck getting a job‚Äô
item.description:
New York University is withholding a diploma from a student commencement speaker who called the conflict in Gaza a ‚Äúgenocide,‚Äù in remarks one Democrat lawmaker blasted as ‚Äústupid, selfish‚Äù lies ‚Äî even going so far as to tell him, ‚Äúgood luck getting a job.‚Äù

NYU Gallatin School‚Äôs student commencement speaker Logan Rozos used the sentimental platform to rail against the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict in a violation of preestablished guidelines, the university said in a statement.

‚ÄúThe only thing that is appropriate to say in this time, and to a group this large, is a recognition of the atrocities currently happening in Palestine,‚Äù Rozos said to an applauding crowd at the Beacon Theatre, video shared online showed.

‚ÄúI want to say that the genocide currently occurring is supported politically and militarily by the United States, is paid for by our tax dollars,‚Äù he continued as students continued to clap.

‚ÄúI just want to say I condemn this genocide and complicity in this genocide,‚Äù Rozos declared as his graduation cap fell off his head.

NYU officials swiftly condemned the speech in a statement calling out Rozos for using the platform to share ‚Äúpersonal and one-sided political views‚Äù and for lying to the university.

‚ÄúNYU strongly denounces the choice by a student at the Gallatin School‚Äôs graduation today at Gallatin School‚Äôs graduation today,‚Äù John Beckman, senior vice president for public affairs and strategic communications.¬†

‚ÄúHe lied about the speech he was going to deliver and violated the commitment he made to comply with our rules. The University is withholding his diploma while we pursue disciplinary actions,‚Äù he stated.

Rep. Jared Moskowitz (D.-Fla.) took Rozos to task for lying and said NYU has every right to withhold the diploma from Gallatin, which is a liberal arts school.

‚ÄúHe lied to the university. Second of all, he lied to everyone listening. There‚Äôs no genocide going on in Israel. There is a war, it‚Äôs unfortunate,‚Äù Moskowitz said Thursday on CNN‚Äôs ‚ÄúNews Night with Abby Phillip,‚Äù The Hill reported.

‚ÄúBut at the end of the day, that‚Äôs up to the university whether they give him his diploma or not,‚Äù he added.

‚ÄúYou know, in fact, they can give him his diploma, it‚Äôs not going to matter. Good luck getting a job. That was a stupid, selfish thing ‚Äî ruined the ceremony for a lot of families,‚Äù Moskowitz charged.

Whether Rozos will receive his diploma is still in the air ‚Äî but the university indicated that further penalties could be levied against the former student.

‚ÄúNYU is deeply sorry that the audience was subjected to these remarks and that this moment was stolen by someone who abused a privilege that was conferred upon him,‚Äù Beckman said.

NYU did not reply to The Post‚Äôs request for comment Friday.
item.author: Shane Galvin

item.title: Ê≠¶Ë£ÖË≠¶ÂØüÂú®Ê∑∑‰π±ÁöÑÂ∞ÅÈîÅÊúüÈó¥Êâ´Ëç°Â§ßÂéÖÔºåÂêìÂùè‰∫ÜÈïøÂ≤õÂ≠¶ÁîüË¢´Ëø´ÂÆåÊàêÂÜ≥Ëµõ | Terrified Long Island students forced to finish finals as armed police swept halls during chaotic lockdown
item.description:
Students inside a Long Island high school said they were left terrified and confused during the response to a hoax shooting threat Thursday ‚Äî and some said they were even forced to keep taking their tests as armed officers cleared the building room by room.

Teens inside Long Beach High School said they had no idea what was going on when the school went into lockdown, and described a chaotic scene of panicking students barricading themselves into classrooms or hiding under their desk for hours as cops stormed the halls.

Some students, who were only in school to take a test that day, said they were watched over by heavily-armed officers with loaded rifles as they were forced to finish, unable to focus on the exam and still unaware of what was happening.

‚ÄúTypically you stop the test and go hide,‚Äù senior Nick Melnikov, who was in the gym taking a Spanish final when the lockdown went into full-effect said. ‚ÄúBut they were like ‚Äònah go finish your test,‚Äô and then the cops walked in and were watching over us with guns as we took our test.‚Äù

Melnikov, whose exam was scheduled to end at 10:30 a.m., said he wasn‚Äôt allowed to leave until 2:30 p.m., stuck in the school and shuffled from room to room for hours after finishing his test.

Other students, like senior Sophia Ferrera, were in class when the lockdown started and said she and her classmates spent over 90 minutes in a dark room silently hiding under their desks until police cleared them.

Despite being traumatized by the situation, she said the worst part was that school officials then made students return to class as if nothing had happened.

‚ÄúI thought they were just going to let everyone go home,‚Äù Ferrera said, shocked that she was forced to go to her next class after that experience.

‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt focus, for the rest of the day I just kind of floated. Nothing felt real,‚Äù she said.

After police cleared the building, the lockdown was downgraded to a ‚Äúlockout,‚Äù meaning nobody is allowed to enter or exit the building ‚Äî but students arriving later in the day for their tests were being let inside all afternoon, while those inside were not allowed to leave, The Post confirmed.

The threat, which turned out to be a hoax call made from California, claimed a 15-year-old student armed with an assault rifle was targeting Long Beach High School because he was ‚Äútired of being bullied.‚Äù

Parents, meanwhile, said they were kept in the dark throughout the entire crisis ‚Äî unable to pick up their children despite seeing students enter and only learning about the situation through frantic text messages from their kids.

‚ÄúI think the police handled it beautifully, but I think the school dropped the ball,‚Äù said Joe Meola, whose child barricaded herself in a classroom with a desk against the door for over two hours.

‚ÄúThey didn‚Äôt tell any parent what was clearly happening or what our kids were actually going through ‚Äî and my daughter was freaking out, she was having panic attacks and said she felt like she was going to throw up,‚Äù Meola added.

He and other parents are now questioning what would happen if a similar situation were to unfold next year, as cellphones are now banned in schools statewide.

‚ÄúNext year the kids cannot have cell phones ‚Äî what if something like this happens again, God forbid,‚Äù asked Mike Doty.

The Long Beach School District declined to comment.
item.author: Brandon Cruz

item.title: ÂèØÁà±ÁöÑÂ∞èÁå´Âú®‰ªéÊ≥¢Â£´È°øÂà∞Êñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÁöÑ250Ëã±Èáå‰πãÊóÖ‰∏≠Âπ∏Â≠ò‰∏ãÊù•‚ÄîÂêåÊó∂Ë¢´Âõ∞Âú®ÂÆùÈ©¨ÂÜÖÈÉ® | Adorable kitten survives 250-mile trip from Boston to New Jersey ‚Äî while stuck inside BMW
item.description:
Eight lives left!

An adorable kitten made a harrowing 250-mile journey from Boston to New Jersey while trapped in the undercarriage of a BMW ‚Äî and now she needs a fur-ever home, her rescuers said Friday.

The six-week-old kitty, who has since been aptly named Beemer, was rescued from the pricey electric vehicle after the car‚Äôs owner heard an odd sound coming from its wheel well at his South Orange home Monday.

‚ÄúI plugged the car in to charge it and heard a ‚Äòmeow,‚Äù said Jeff¬†Rothstein. ‚ÄúI was like, Oh my God, what just happened?‚Äù

Rothstein, who had just driven the gleaming 2025 ride back from Beantown with his wife, Lauri, said he had no clue there was a furry stowaway on board.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt imagine what that little cat was going through,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs one tough cat.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe would have jumped out if we had heard anything,‚Äù Lauri added.

The sweet-faced, black-and-white kitten, who had likely slipped into the vehicle‚Äôs body to stay warm, refused to come out despite hours of effort from firefighters,‚Äù said Whitney Malin, a local animal rescuer who helped the¬†Rothsteins save the feline. ‚ÄúThe cat was petrified.‚Äù

‚ÄúI had tuna and bacon and was playing YouTube videos of kittens crying, which usually works,‚Äù Malin said.‚ÄúIt was three hours of me lying under the car and the fire department trying ‚Äî and it didn‚Äôt work.‚Äù

The Rothsteins were good sports about letting firefighters ‚Äújack up‚Äù their luxury vehicle, Malin said.

¬†‚ÄúI can‚Äôt even believe [they] allowed the fire department to rip apart their $80,000 car,‚Äù she said.

Malin returned the next day ‚Äî this time armed with ‚Äúa ton of pre-cooked bacon‚Äù ‚Äî to lure the feisty feline into a humane animal trap.

‚ÄúI was able to get her into the trap and then in a carrier with a fuzzy blanket,‚Äù Malin said. ‚ÄúI fed her and she was all hissy ‚Äî but turns out she is super sweet.‚Äù

The kitten, who has since gotten a clean bill of health, is still in South Orange and is now searching for a home.

She has a meeting with someone who potentially wants to adopt her Friday, Malin said.¬†

It‚Äôs good luck that the kitty lived to tell the tail, er, tale, she said.

‚ÄúShe would have lived her life in a BMW dealership parking lot,‚Äù Malin said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a happy ending.‚Äù
item.author: Natalie O'Neill

item.title: ËÅîÈÇ¶Ë∞ÉÊü•Â±ÄÂú®Sean ‚ÄòDiddy‚Äò CombsÈÖíÂ∫óÊàøÈó¥ÂÜÖÂèëÁé∞Â©¥ÂÑøÊ≤π„ÄÅÊ∂¶ÊªëÊ≤πÂíåÊëáÂ§¥‰∏∏ | Feds found baby oil, lube, ecstasy inside Sean ‚ÄòDiddy‚Äô Combs‚Äô hotel room
item.description:
Special Agent Yasin Binda ‚Äî with the Department of Homeland Security ‚Äî testified about how the feds found baby oil and lubricant stashed all over the hotel room where Sean ‚ÄúDiddy‚Äù Combs had been arrested.

The agents raided room 2115 at the Park Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan on Sept. 16, 2024 after Combs‚Äô arrest that day, finding bags of Astroglide lubricant and baby oil inside the entryway closet of the room. They also found more lube in the bathroom and in the nightstand of the room, according to Binda‚Äôs testimony and photos shown to the jury.

Also a pill bottle of Klonopin written for ‚ÄúFrank Black,‚Äù an apparently fake name, was found inside a Louis Vuitton bag on the nightstand.

Inside the nightstand drawer, were pink-colored drugs, which were ketamine and MDMA, Binda said.

Jurors were given the bag of pink drugs to look at and pass around.

During this testimony, Combs put his hand on his forehead and patted his head, while he spoke to his lawyers.
item.author: Kyle Schnitzer, Priscilla DeGregory

item.title: ÈáäÊîæÂìàÈ©¨ÊñØ‰∫∫Ë¥®ÔºåÂèÇÂä†Êú¨Âë®Êú´Âú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶‰∏æË°åÁöÑ‰ª•Ëâ≤ÂàóÊó•Ê∏∏Ë°åÔºö ‚ÄúÊàë‰ª¨‰∏ç‰ºöÂÅú‰∏ãÊù•ÔºåÁõ¥Âà∞ÊØè‰∏™‰∫∫ÈÉΩÂõûÂÆ∂‚Äù | Freed Hamas hostages to march in NY‚Äôs Israel Day Parade this weekend: ‚ÄòWe won‚Äôt stop until everyone is home‚Äô
item.description:
Hamas hostage survivors will march down Fifth Avenue on Sunday as part of New York‚Äôs annual Israel Day Parade ‚Äî to continue the push to free the remaining 58 captives.

Keith and Aviva Siegel, Doron Steinbracher, Ilana Gritzewsky and Eliya Cohen are expected to join as many as 40,000 other demonstrators for the parade, showing solidarity for Israel as well as advocating for the plight of the hostages.

‚ÄúWe will march together, standing with the families and released hostages, and making our message unmistakably clear: Nothing is more important than bringing them home ‚Äî all of them. We won‚Äôt stop until everyone is home,‚Äù the Jewish Community Relations Council said in a statement.

This year‚Äôs theme is, fittingly, ‚ÄúHatikvah,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúthe hope‚Äù in Hebrew. It is also the title of Israel‚Äôs national anthem.

The parade logo for 2025 is a multi-colored tree with a yellow ribbon in its center, which has been used to signify support for the 251 people who were abducted by Hamas during the Oct. 7 attack.

The Siegels and Gritzeweky were freed from captivity in November 2023 during the first cease-fire deal with Hamas, while Steinbracher and Cohen endured nearly 500 days of torture.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just impossible to grasp, and there are no words to describe the lack of understanding in our country about what is taking place 50 meters underground,‚Äù¬†Cohen said after his release.

It will be the second march since the outbreak of the Israel-Gaza war, and its mission has since pivoted from celebrating the Jewish culture to stamping out antisemitism and renewing demands to free the remaining hostages.

The procession will start at 11:30 a.m. at 62nd Street and continue north to 74th Street.
item.author: Katherine Donlevy

item.title: Dawn Richard‰ΩúËØÅËØ¥ÔºåÂ•πÁúãÂà∞Sean ‚ÄúDiddy‚Äù Combs ‚ÄúÁªèÂ∏∏‚Äù‰∏éCassie VenturaÂèëÁîüÊö¥Âäõ‰∫ã‰ª∂ | Dawn Richard testifies she saw Sean ‚ÄòDiddy‚Äô Combs get violent with Cassie Ventura ‚Äòoften‚Äô
item.description:
Dawn Richard testified about how once in 2009 she saw a ‚Äúbelligerent‚Äù Sean ‚ÄúDiddy‚Äù Combs attack Cassie Ventura.

Richard said Combs was ‚Äúscreaming, belligerent, asking where his food was and proceeded to hit [Ventura] over the head and beat her on the ground in front of us.‚Äù

Richard said she saw the Bad Boy Records founder get violent with Ventura ‚Äúoften.‚Äù

Richard ‚Äî a singer in a band founded by Combs, Danity Kane ‚Äî described how Combs screamed ‚Äúwhere the f‚Äìk was his eggs‚Äù and then took a skillet with the eggs inside and tried to his Ventura over the head with the pan.

Ventura managed to partially deflect the pan by balling up into the fetal position on the floor, Richard said.

But then Combs continued the vicious beating by punching and kicking Ventura before putting his arm around her neck, grabbing her hair and dragging her upstairs, Richard testified.

She said she was so shocked and scared that she didn‚Äôt intervene or go to the police over what she saw and the next day Combs locked Richard and another person in he recording studio in his house and threatened them.

‚ÄúHe said what we saw was passion and what lovers in passionate relationships do,‚Äù Richard recalled. ‚ÄúHe said [Ventura] was OK and it would be in our best interests if we didn‚Äôt say anything.‚Äù

Combs told them he was trying to take them to the top of the industry before menacingly saying, ‚Äúwhere he was from, people go missing if they talk,‚Äù the witness said.

Then he gave them flowers, Richard said.

She said she understood Combs was threatening ‚Äúdeath.‚Äù
item.author: Jack Morphet, Kyle Schnitzer, Priscilla DeGregory

item.title: Êñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÂ∑û‰ºóËÆÆÂëò‰πîÂ∏å¬∑ÊààÁâπÊµ∑ÈªòÔºà Josh Gottheimer ÔºâÂëºÂêÅÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∑ûÂ∑ûÈïøÂáØË•ø¬∑Èúç‰∏òÂ∞îÔºà Kathy Hochul ÔºâÂú®Êñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÂ∑ûÂÖ¨ÂÖ±‰∫§ÈÄöÁΩ¢Â∑•ÁªìÊùü‰πãÂâçÂÜªÁªì | NJ Rep. Josh Gottheimer calls on NY Gov. Kathy Hochul to freeze congestion pricing until NJ Transit strike is over
item.description:
New Jersey Rep. Josh Gottheimer called on New York Gov. Kathy Hochul to freeze the city‚Äôs controversial congestion pricing until the NJ Transit strike that‚Äôs wreaking havoc on commuters is over, he said Friday.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm asking for Gov. Hochul to freeze congestion tax for people who are having to drive in [to the city] now and, of course, our tolls in New Jersey because I‚Äôve heard from a lot of people [who say] their costs are up,‚Äù the Democratic congressman said during a press call.

‚ÄúWe need to give them some relief until this is over,‚Äù he said, adding the tax should be scrapped until trains are running again.

He also demanded a full reimbursement of tolls ‚Äî including from the Port Authority, E-Z Pass, and the New Jersey Turnpike Authority ‚Äî for New Jersey riders who have a NJ Transit monthly unlimited trips pass.

NJ Transit failed to reach a contract agreement with locomotive engineers Wednesday, triggering the first major transit strike to hit the Garden State in more than 40 years.

The strike was a travel nightmare Friday for the roughly 70,000 riders who go into Manhattan daily, as some train stations sat eerily empty. Up to 350,000 commuters statewide may have also been left stranded by the halted service.

Gottheimer, who last year called Hochul‚Äôs revived congestion pricing plan ‚Äúinsane,‚Äù said the strike has also put local businesses and commuters in ‚Äúa tough spot.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt afford to have our great transit system frozen,‚Äù he said, urging both sides to stick out negotiations. ‚ÄúGrab that pot of coffee and stay at the table.‚Äù

Gottheimer, a moderate representing the bedroom communities that border the Jersey side of the Hudson River near the George Washington Bridge, added that, ‚ÄúCongress should step in‚Äù if the parties can‚Äôt work it out on their own.

Hochul‚Äôs congestion pricing plan charges a $9 toll for vehicles entering Manhattan south of 60th Street during peak hours, generating tens of millions of dollars in monthly revenue.

‚ÄúRepresentative Gottheimer should focus on helping to resolve the dispute with New Jersey‚Äôs dedicated transit workers instead of looking to New York for a bailout,‚Äù a spokesperson for Gov. Kathy Hochul wrote to The Post in a statement Friday.
item.author: Natalie O'Neill, Vaughn Golden

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶FDNY EMTÁöÑÊ≠ª‰∫°Ë¢´ÊåáÊéßÁöÑÁñØÂ≠êËå´ÁÑ∂Âú∞ÂáùËßÜÁùÄÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÊ≥ïÈô¢Ê≠£Âú®ËøõË°åÊÆãÈÖ∑ÁöÑÂàÄÂáªÔºö ‚ÄúËøôÁúüÁöÑ‰ª§‰∫∫‰∏çÂÆâ‚Äù | Maniac charged in FDNY EMT‚Äôs death stares blankly as brutal knifing is played in NYC court: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs really disturbing‚Äô
item.description:
The maniac accused of ruthlessly knifing a beloved FDNY EMS lieutenant to death did a bizarre stint on the stand at his murder trial Friday ‚Äî and chillingly showed no emotion when confronted with videos of the horrific, random attack.

Peter Zisopoulos, 36, stared intensely into the gallery in Queens Supreme Court ‚Äî packed with teary-eyed EMS personnel ‚Äî as prosecutors played footage of a man knocking over 9/11 first-responder Alison Russo-Elling, getting on top of her and stabbing her 19 times on an Astoria sidewalk.

‚ÄúIt may look like a past picture of mine,‚Äù Zisopoulos, seemingly unfazed by the brutal videos, admitted on the stand.

The alleged killer denied being the man in the video, saying the corner where the savage 2022 attack took place looked ‚Äúa little bit‚Äù familiar.

The video showed the killer enter Zisopoulos‚Äô Astoria apartment building, but he replied ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know‚Äù when asked if the attacker went into the unit he shared with his mother.

Trial attendees ‚Äî who included Russo-Elling‚Äôs grieving daughter ‚Äî wept openly as the two graphic videos played.

The courtroom gallery became exasperated, with some rolling their eyes, as Zisopoulos was repeatedly caught in apparent lies during his testimony.

For instance, Zisopoulos ‚Äî dressed in an orange Department of Correction jumpsuit and sporting black eye-glasses ‚Äî claimed he was asleep in his apartment when Russo-Elling, 61, was killed while on her lunch break, just a half-block¬†from her stationhouse Sept. 29, 2022.

Prosecutors pointed out that Zisopoulos told The Post in a jailhouse interview a year after the murder that he had been home watching ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù and that surveillance video of the attack was ‚Äúphotoshopped‚Äù to frame him.

He‚Äôd apparently given police a third version, saying he‚Äôd woken up at 8 a.m., eaten breakfast, watched the news and then gone back to sleep, until he was awoken by cops knocking at his door.

‚ÄúYou gave an interview to a New York Post reporter, and you told the New York Post reporter that you were watching Star Wars. So just to be clear, you told the police that you were watching the news, you told a reporter that you were watching ‚ÄòStar Wars‚Äô and you now told all of us that you were just sleeping?‚Äù Queens Assistant District Attorney Johnathan Selkowe pressed.

‚ÄúThose are all three different things.‚Äù

Zisopoulos simply responded: ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

The accused killer was also tripped up when he Selkowe asked him how he had sustained a fresh cut on his hand the day of the crime.

On the stand, Zisopoulos claimed he was knifed by police officers after he refused to open the door for them.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt answer because I don‚Äôt trust them. The police are really mean to me,‚Äù Zisopoulos said when questioned by his public defender, Gina Mitchell.

‚ÄúThey called SWAT & SWAT stabbed my hand. I tried to cover the peephole and they push the knife through the peephole,‚Äù he ranted. ‚ÄúI bled out and SWAT opened the door.‚Äù¬†

But the prosecutor pointed out that Zisopoulos had told cops his hand was sliced a month earlier, but that the wound had recently reopened.

Selkowe also pushed Zisopoulos on his reasoning for trying to leave cops waiting in his hallway, getting the alleged killer to admit he had a knife in his pocket at the time.

‚ÄúYou understood that if the police came in, they would find the man with the knife?‚Äù the prosecutor asked.

Zisopoulo answered: ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù¬†

When asked if it was the same knife used to kill Russo-Elling, rather than one he used to eat breakfast, Zisopoulos could only answer, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know.‚Äù

His lawyers tried to move for the case to be dismissed, saying prosecutors did not provide evidence to prove intent beyond a reasonable doubt, a move that sent shock through the courtroom.

The bid was promptly rejected and court dismissed. Jury deliberations will begin on Monday.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe this guy has the nerve to deny all of this, when it‚Äôs clear as day from multiple different angles what occurred,‚Äù the victim‚Äôs daughter, Danielle Russo, told The Post after court. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a real shame that he‚Äôs walking the earth, and among us.‚Äù

She said the weekend break was a welcome one, and expressed hope she would return Monday to see Zisopoulos convicted.

‚ÄúHopefully this man never sees the sun outside in the free world ever again,‚Äù Russo said.

‚ÄúJust can‚Äôt wait for my family to get justice and this be at rest,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs pretty difficult to even see him up there and act so nonchalant about such a vicious and savage attack that he just denies and says he was sleeping through. It‚Äôs unreal.‚Äù

Russo added, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs actually pretty sad to see the person that he took from us and everything she‚Äôs done and contributed to the community and everything she did throughout her life ‚Äî and how someone like this can just not care at all. It‚Äôs really disturbing.‚Äù¬†
item.author: Desheania Andrews, Katherine Donlevy

item.title: Âèç‰ª•Ëâ≤ÂàóÊäóËÆÆËÄÖÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶‚ÄúNakba Day‚ÄùÊ∏∏Ë°å‰∏≠Ë¢´ÊçïÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Ë≠¶ÂØüËøΩÊçïÁî®ÈáëÂ±ûË∑ØÈöúÊÆ¥ÊâìË≠¶ÂØüÁöÑË†ïÂèòÔºöË≠¶ÂØü | Anti-Israel protesters busted in NYC ‚ÄòNakba Day‚Äô march as cops hunt creep who bashed officer with metal barricade: cops
item.description:
Eight anti-Israel protesters were busted during a wild march late Thursday ‚Äì and cops are still hunting a ski mask-wearing agitator who bashed an NYPD cop in the face with a metal barricade, police said.¬†

The march ‚Äì led by the notorious Within Our Lifetime group ‚Äì began at Cadman Plaza, continued over the Brooklyn Bridge, and passed through City Hall Park, Union Square Park and finally Madison Square Park.

By around 8:15 p.m., as protesters converged on Union Square Park, an unidentified agitator tried to stop the 39-year-old officer from moving a metal barricade, cops said.¬†

As the aggressor struggled to hold onto the barrier, he slammed it into the cop‚Äôs face, authorities said.¬†

The suspect then ran off and had not been caught by Friday. Police released a photo of the man, last seen wearing all black, in hopes of tracking him down.¬†

The injured officer was taken to a local hospital, where he was listed in stable condition, police said.¬†

Meanwhile, video from the park shows one demonstrator who had climbed on top of the iconic bronze George Washington sculpture inside the park straddling the shoulders of the figure as the NYPD used a cherry picker to bring him down.¬†

He is shown being led away in handcuffs, but his name and charges were not immediately known.¬†

Of the eight people in custody, five were formally arrested and charged and three were slapped with summonses for disorderly conduct, according to the NYPD.

It‚Äôs unclear what the other charges were.

The march was held on ‚ÄúNakba Day‚Äù ‚Äî marking what Palestinians call the ‚Äúcatastrophe‚Äù of Israel‚Äôs founding on May 14, 1948.

The rally came three days before the annual Israel Day Parade is set to kick off on Manhattan‚Äôs Fifth Avenue.

There are ‚Äúno specific or credible threats‚Äù directed toward the parade, NYPD Commissioner Jessica Tisch said Friday.

‚ÄúBut as always, we remain vigilant that the public can expect to see a robust and visible police presence throughout the area,‚Äù the top cop told reporters.

Mayor Eric Adams said the city is well-prepared for any protests that may surround the gathering, which spans from 62nd to 74th streets.

‚ÄúIt is not our prediction, it is our preparation,‚Äù Adams said. ‚ÄúIf we practice, we‚Äôre always ready. No matter what we face, we see over and over again, even of these sporadic pop-up protests that you witnessed, the city is able to move on with their daily activities.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo we will be prepared, and that‚Äôs why we are creating an environment where we can inspect who‚Äôs coming into the parade site, how we‚Äôre going to control the flow of people and ensure that we have proper deployment of personnel.‚Äù
item.author: Amanda Woods

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Âú∞Âå∫ÁöÑÁÅ´ËΩ¶Á´ôÂºÇÂ∏∏Á©∫Ëç°Ëç°ÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Êñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÂ∑û‰∫§ÈÄöÂ±ÄÁöÑÁΩ¢Â∑•‰ΩøÁπÅÂøôÁöÑÊúçÂä°Èô∑ÂÖ•ÂÅúÈ°ø | NYC-area train stations eerily empty as NJ Transit strike brings bustling service to a grinding halt
item.description:
Last call for the ghost train to Jersey.

Normally bustling transit terminals were eerily empty Friday as NJ Transit engineers went on strike, bringing rail services across the state to a grinding halt and leaving hubs like Penn Station in New York eerily devoid of Garden State travelers.

The platforms at the Manhattan transit stop had a post-apocalyptic feel during the early Friday rush hour after the NJ Transit engineers walked off the job over a pay dispute, triggering the first strike to hit the major transport system in more than 40 years.

The strike ‚Äî which left roughly 350,000 commuters in the lurch ‚Äî left scores of train terminals in the Garden State, including the Harrison PATH station, virtually bare, too, as people relied on buses, cars, taxis and boats¬†to get to work.

‚ÄúI left home very early because of it,‚Äù David Milosevich, a fashion and advertising casting director, said as he arrived at Midtown‚Äôs Port Authority Bus Terminal from Montclair, NJ, first thing.

Given Friday‚Äôs rail commute into New York from New Jersey is typically the lightest of the week, Milosevich and other passengers were already bracing for chaos if the strikes stretched over into Monday.

‚ÄúI think a lot of people don‚Äôt come in on Fridays since COVID.¬†I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going to happen Monday,‚Äù Milosevich said.

‚ÄúFriday most people work at home, so today it was business as usual,‚Äù Cem Teber, a 31-year-old lawyer, told The Post after being forced to ditch his train in favor of a bus from North Bergen.

‚ÄúThe real test will be next week, come back here on Wednesday and see how it is.‚Äù

Anthony Wilkerson, 34, who lives in West Orange, NJ, said he managed to snag ‚Äúa seat to myself this morning‚Äù given it was Friday ‚Äî but feared the bus system next week would overrun.

Early indications were that the strike hadn‚Äôt resulted in any major traffic jams or epically long lines to get onto buses.

But as the morning rush got underway, some commuters ‚Äî including those unable to work remotely and ones just caught-of-guard by the strikes ‚Äî were desperately searching for other modes of transport that wouldn‚Äôt cost a bomb.

‚ÄúI went to check out Amtrak. It was $108. I don‚Äôt have that. I only have $70 in my pocket,‚Äù contractor, Victory, 63, told The Post as he tried to get from Manhattan to his construction job in Trenton, NJ.

Desperate for a paycheck, Victory said his boss told him to catch a bus from Port Authority ‚Äî even though it would likely take three hours.

Here is the latest on the NJ transit strike:

  • NJ Transit nixes train, bus service to Shakira concerts at MetLife over looming strike
  • NJ Transit strike could strand 350K riders ‚Äî and the emergency backup plan won‚Äôt solve the problem
  • New Jersey bracing for summer of travel hell with NJ Transit strike, Newark airport delays and I-80 sinkhole: ‚ÄòGoing to be ugly‚Äô
  • NJ Transit engineers on strike after contract negotiations fail ‚Äî wreaking havoc on commuters
